block.p: The New York City Board of Education's new teacher assignment policy of sending certified teachers only to the most troubled schools (news article, Sept. 7) is shortsighted.

This policy will result in new teacher candidates' remaining uncertified in order to have a choice in where they will teach. Thus, the policy will have an effect that is the opposite of what Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, intended.
The New York City Board of Education's new teacher assignment policy of sending certified teachers only to the most troubled schools (news article, Sept. 7) is shortsighted.

This policy will result in new teacher candidates' remaining uncertified in order to have a choice in where they will teach. Thus, the policy will have an effect that is the opposite of what Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, intended.
While we try to solve the problems of the lowest-performing schools, the shortage of certified teachers in New York City will be worsened.
The writer is dean of the School of Education, Long Island University.
